highlights.para: The Package Manager application is a graphical user interface for the Image Packaging System (IPS) software. The Package Manger allows you to search, install, and remove packages; add, and modify repositories; and create and remove boot environments.

sect1.title: To Start Package Manager
sect1.para: You can start the Package Manager in the following ways:

listitem.para: Click System Administration Package Manager.
Execute the following command at the prompt:

sect1.title: When You Start Package Manager
sect1.para: When you start the Package Manager ,the following window is displayed: (todo insert screen shot)
The main window of the Package Manager is divided into the following elements :

listitem.para: You can browse the available packages by category. The dropdown menu shows the list of categories available.
The Show dropdown menu allows you to filter the list of packages by the options listed below:
All Packages– Shows the list of all packages available in the current (todo) repository.
Installed Packages – Shows the list of packages installed on your system.
Selected Packages – Shows the list of packages you have selected.
Updates Available — Shows the list of packages that have newer versions available in the current repository.
The toolbar contains the icons for a subset of the commands that can be performed by using the menus on the menubar.
You can access the menus on the menubar to perform all of the commands related to the Package Manager.
The list of packages in the selected category and a brief description are displayed here.
Click on a package to select it. Details of the selected package such as name, version, file dependencies, are displayed in this window.
The list of available repositories are shown in the repository dropdown menu. Click on a repository name to select it.

note.para: Click the Reload button to reload the Package Manager and view the list of the packages from the newly—selected repository.

sect1.title: Install a Package
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to install a package:

listitem.para: In the main window of the Package Manager, click the Reload button in order to view the latest list of the packages available to you.
Check the box next to the package to select it.
Click on Install/Update in the toolbar to start the package installation process.
You can also choose Package Install/Update to start the package installation process.
The Package Manager checks for dependencies. Click Show Details to view the details.
Click Cancel to cancel the package installation. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.
The Install Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the package installation information and the package dependencies.
Click Cancel to cancel the package installation. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.
The packages are downloaded and installed.
Click the Reload button to view the updated list of packages.

sect1.title: Remove a Package
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to remove a package:

listitem.para: Check the box next to the package you want to remove.
Click the Remove button in the toolbar to start the process.
You can also choose Package Remove to remove a package.
The Remove Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the packages to be removed and the package dependencies.
Click OK to proceed. After you click the OK button, you cannot undo the package removal.
Click Cancel to cancel the process. No changes are made and you are returned to the main window.
Click the Reload button to view the updated list of packages.

sect1.title: Search for a Package
sect1.para: Type the name of the package you want to search for in the Search box.
The following search parameters are available:

listitem.para: Name, Description or Keyword –
Maintainer –
Dependencies –
Commands –

sect1.para: Use the submenus under the Edit menu to cut, copy, paste, or clear text in the Search tab.

sect1.title: Update a Package
sect1.para: Look for the green icon next to the installed package name. This icon indicates that updates are available for the package in the currently selected repository. Select the package and click on the Install/Update button to install the latest version of the package.

sect1.title: Switch Between Configured Repositories
sect1.para: Use the Repositories drop-down menu on the toolbar to view a list of configured repositories. Click on a repository name to switch to a different repository.

sect1.title: Update the Current Image (Update All Packages)
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to update your entire image :

listitem.para: Click File Update All or the Update All button to start the process of updating all the packages in your image.

note.para: The Update All button is enabled when updates are available to the installed packages.

listitem.para: The Update All Confirmation dialog box is displayed.

During the Update All process, a clone of the active boot environment is created. This clone enables the user to rollback the system to the current boot environment if the Update All process fails to complete or if it or corrupts the system.
Enter a name for the new boot environment clone that will be created.

note.para: It is recommended that users enter meaningful names for the boot environment clone. For example, OpenSolaris_11/15/08 , clearly shows that the boot environment clone is a clone of the OpenSolaris OS and was created on 11/15/08.

listitem.para: Click Proceed to continue the Update All process.
Click Cancel to cancel the process. No changes are made to the boot environment and the you are returned to the main window of the Package Manager.

sect2.title: Update All Errors
sect2.para: A new boot environment clone must be created for the Update All process to be completed. An error message is displayed if a boot environment clone cannot be created. You may see the following error message dialog box:
Not enough disk space: the Update All action cannot be performed. You may choose to return BE Management to manage your boot environments and free up disk space.
Perform the following steps if you wish to rectify the error and continue with the Update All process:

listitem.para: Click BE Management to go to the BE Management dialog box.
Follow the steps listed in to delete old or unused boot environments and free up disk space.
After you have rebooted your system, click the Update All icon to restart the process of updating all packages.

sect1.title: Manage Boot Environments
sect1.para: For an OpenSolaris release, a boot environment is an instance of a bootable OpenSolaris environment. The boot environment consists of a root file system and, optionally, other file systems, such as /usr, /var, or /export. These other file systems are mounted below the root file system. The root file system and all other file systems of the boot environment that contain system software are required to be zfs datasets.

An active boot environment is the one that is currently booted. Exactly one active boot environment can be booted. An inactive boot environment is not currently booted, but can be in a state of waiting for activation on the next reboot.
Perform the following steps to manage your Boot Environments (BE):

listitem.para: Click on File Boot Environment Management.
The Boot Environment Management dialog box is displayed. In this dialog box, you can perform the following actions:
Select the radio button next to the boot environment that you want to boot into upon system reboot. This is the default boot environment.

term.emphasis: Remove old or unused boot environments to free up disk space.

listitem.para: Select the checkbox next to the boot environment you want to delete.
Click OK to proceed.
Click Reset to revert the changes to the opening state.
Click Cancel to cancel all changes and return to the main window.
If you clicked OK , the BE Management Confirmation dialog box is displayed. Review the changes to the boot environment and click OK to proceed.

note.para: The changes made will take effect only after system reboot.

listitem.para: Click Cancel to cancel the changes and return to the BE Management dialog box.
Reboot your system.

sect1.title: Edit Repositories
sect1.para: Perform the following steps to add, remove, or configure repositories:

listitem.para: Click Settings Edit Repositories.
The Manage Repositories dialog box is displayed. The following actions can be performed in this dialog box:
Add a Repository – To add a new repository, enter the name and the address (URL) of the repository. Click Add.
Remove a Repository – To remove a repository, click on a repository name from the list to select it. Click Remove.

note.para: A repository that has been set as preferred repository cannot be removed. To remove a preferred repository, set a non-preferred repository as preferred, and then remove the repository.

listitem.para: A preferred repository is the default repository where the source for the packages are downloaded from. (edit)

To set a repository as a preferred repository, click the radio button next to the repository you would like to set as preferred repository. Click Close if you are not making any other changes to the repository information.
Modify a Repository – Perform the following steps to modify a repository :
Select the repository you want to modify.
Click the Modify button. The Modify Repository dialog box is displayed.
Type a valid name for the repository and the URL of the repository. A repository name is considered valid if it does not exist in the current list of repositories.
Click OK to save the changes and return to the Manage Repositories dialog box.
Click Cancel to cancel your changes. You are returned to the Manage Repositories dialog box.
